awd_titl_txt: BIGDATA: F: Models, Algorithms, and Software for Spatial-Relational Networks
awd_abstract_narration:
Many important big-data problems can be modeled as networks in which nodes are mapped in physical space. To address these problems, the project investigates a novel network abstraction called a spatial-relational network. This abstraction targets a broad class of applications with unique big-data challenges, including financial fraud, epidemiology, and systems engineering. The distinguishing feature of spatial-relational networks is that the network component models relationships that correspond to fundamentally non-spatial modes of influence and information flow, whereas the spatial relationships represent a different type of heterogeneous interaction. As an example, in the human connectome, edges correspond to regions of the brain that fire together, whereas spatial proximity reflects patho-physiological aspects such as the existence of a lesion. This project aims to develop models, methods, and software for important analysis problems on spatial-relational networks as well as validate them on a range of real-world problems. The project enables fundamentally new analytic techniques in many applications while significantly enhancing the accuracy and efficiency of analyses techniques in others. These range from novel fraud detection algorithms in online transactions to study of onset and progression of neurodegenerative diseases such as Alzheimer's and Parkinson's. Beyond its research and applications' impact, the project also targets a number of educational contributions. These include development of a curriculum for data sciences, online modules on big-data analytics, workshops and tutorials on the spatial-relational network abstraction at major conferences, and opportunities for undergraduate research.

This project establishes the foundations of spatial-relational networks as a fundamental and scalable big-data abstraction that enables novel analyses. It aims to derive efficient and effective computational representations for spatial-networks, high-performance algorithms for spatial-relational networks, modeling and analysis of dynamic spatial-relational networks in which the node relations and attributes are dynamic, but their spatial locations are fixed.  Project goals include software development and comprehensive validation on selected applications in the analysis of data from the Human Connectome Project, the Allen Brain Atlas, and location-based social networks.

por.por_cntn:
Two well-known, common networks are the social network of inter-personal relationships and the Internet. When social networks are studied by computer scientists, such as is done in our project, it is often represented as a collection of people and the friendship relationships among the people. Likewise, the Internet is studied as a collection of servers and the physical or logical connections among the servers. In both cases, the people and servers have a physical presence that is often tied to some specific place in the world. However, most people also have friendships outside of the vicinity of where they reside, and servers often have logical connections to other distant machines as well. The crux of our project was to study these sets of connections -- represented through an abstraction called a graph -- and especially focus on how nearby connections compare to far away connections. Indeed, the scenario motivated by these two ideas is shared by other types of networks studied throughout science including the brain, which was a key motivation of many of the ideas studied in our project.

 

The intellectual merit of our project was to understand what was possible by modeling and studying data where this distinction between spatial connections -- those that are nearby based on location -- and relational connections -- those that are distant and based on different mechanisms -- was handled in algorithms and models in an explicit fashion. Prior work had largely sought to study the scenarios without distinction between the cases of spatial and relational connections.

 

Our project team discovered a number of interesting research findings in the course of the project as we sought to lay the foundations for studying these networks that we called spatial-relational. There was work on pure algorithms and theory. For instance, one of the most common tasks with data is to identify natural groups or regions of the data through a methodology called clustering or partitioning.  Combining these motivations led to a new type of graph clustering objective function that linked previously unrelated methods based on fully connected subgraphs (cliques) with those based on minimum communication efforts. Our research also included new statistical tests for structure in point process data in space and time.

 

As a specific application of our new ideas regards comparing brain networks, or connectomes. A brain connectome represents the functional connections among regions of the brain. Because the brain has both localized processes and distinct functional relationships among brain regions, this data has the same mixture of connections suitable for our methods. A common problem on such data involves aligning networks between two individuals. Such an alignment explains how brain regions relate to each other. Existing techniques use only the location information mapped to a common reference. We developed new algorithms that omit this step and allow the networks to be aligned through an algorithm that seeks to identify shared regions between the two graphs and update how the nodes align based on their spatial positions. This required a new formulation that took edge lengths into account for the alignment process. The resulting algorithm was named rigid graph alignment. When we applied rigid graph alignment to functional brain networks derived from 20 subjects drawn from the Human Connectome Project (HCP) database, we found better matches between the brain regions over methods that only used the structure of the brain connectomes without the locations. This is just one example of how our new methods enable a broad array of new investigations.

 

The broader impact of our work includes training several PhD students. Students funded on this project have continued to become assistant professors in other schools and now have their own independent research programs. There are a variety of software packages and datasets that were created because of this project, such as the alignment software described in our example. These support analyzing connectomes of data as well as novel analyses of graphs and network data. There is a novel repository of data where the graph data have a strong spatial component to the edges and each node has an explicit location in space to support ongoing research and impacts from these ideas into areas such as agriculture and food flows.
